Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A congregant has just passed away and the family needs him to officiate the funeral service very soon.
Story: I was sitting at my kitchen table, phone in hand, staring at the blinking cursor in my stepmother’s chat window. It was Sunday, the day I usually sent her a message to check in, to let her know I was thinking of her and Dad. She always said it meant a lot, especially since I wasn’t her “real” child, and I knew how much she valued these small gestures. But as I started to type, my phone buzzed again—this time, a call from the synagogue. One of our oldest congregants had passed away unexpectedly, and the family needed me to officiate the funeral as soon as possible. My mind raced with the logistics: preparing the eulogy, comforting the mourners, arranging the service. I felt the weight of my community’s expectations pressing down on me, but at the same time, the guilt of neglecting my stepmother tugged at my heart. I couldn’t be in two places at once, and both needed me now. My fingers hovered over the screen, torn between duty and family, as the minutes slipped by.
